csharp_simple:
1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Acceleration Oscillator (AO / AC)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// Developed by Bill Williams to measure acceleration/deceleration of the current driving force.
11 /// Calculated as the difference between the Awesome Oscillator (AO) and a 5-period SMA of the AO.
12 /// </remarks>
13 public class AccelerationOscillator
14 {
15 public int ShortPeriod { get; }
16 public int LongPeriod { get; }
17 public int SmoothedPeriod { get; }
18 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
19​
20 public AccelerationOscillator(int shortPeriod = 5, int longPeriod = 34, int smoothedPeriod = 5)
21 {
22 ShortPeriod = shortPeriod;
23 LongPeriod = longPeriod;
24 SmoothedPeriod = smoothedPeriod;
25 }
26​
27 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
28 {
29 Values.Clear();
30 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
31 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
32​
33 // Step 1: Calculate Median Prices (High + Low) / 2
34 var medianPrices = new List<decimal>();
35 foreach (var c in candleList)
36 medianPrices.Add((c.High + c.Low) / 2);
37​
38 // Step 2: Calculate Awesome Oscillator (AO)
39 // AO = SMA(Median, 5) - SMA(Median, 34)
40 var shortSma = CalculateSma(medianPrices, ShortPeriod);
41 var longSma = CalculateSma(medianPrices, LongPeriod);
42​
43 var aoValues = new List<decimal?>();
44 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
45 {
46 if (shortSma[i].HasValue && longSma[i].HasValue)
47 aoValues.Add(shortSma[i]!.Value - longSma[i]!.Value);
48 else
49 aoValues.Add(null);
50 }
51​
52 // Step 3: Calculate SMA of AO
53 var aoSma = CalculateSmaNullable(aoValues, SmoothedPeriod);
54​
55 // Step 4: AC = AO - SMA(AO, 5)
56 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
57 {
58 if (aoValues[i].HasValue && aoSma[i].HasValue)
59 Values.Add(aoValues[i]!.Value - aoSma[i]!.Value);
60 else
61 Values.Add(null);
62 }
63 }
64​
65 private static List<decimal?> CalculateSma(List<decimal> source, int period)
66 {
67 var results = new List<decimal?>();
68 decimal sum = 0;
69 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
70 {
71 sum += source[i];
72 if (i >= period) sum -= source[i - period];
73
74 if (i < period - 1) results.Add(null);
75 else results.Add(sum / period);
76 }
77 return results;
78 }
79​
80 private static List<decimal?> CalculateSmaNullable(List<decimal?> source, int period)
81 {
82 var results = new List<decimal?>();
83 decimal sum = 0;
84 var window = new Queue<decimal>();
85​
86 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
87 {
88 if (!source[i].HasValue)
89 {
90 results.Add(null);
91 continue;
92 }
93​
94 decimal val = source[i]!.Value;
95 sum += val;
96 window.Enqueue(val);
97​
98 if (window.Count > period) sum -= window.Dequeue();
99​
100 if (window.Count < period) results.Add(null);
101 else results.Add(sum / period);
102 }
103 return results;
104 }
105​
106 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int shortPeriod = 5, int longPeriod = 34, int smoothedPeriod = 5)
107 {
108 var ac = new AccelerationOscillator(shortPeriod, longPeriod, smoothedPeriod);
109 ac.Calculate(candles);
110 return ac.Values;
111 }
112 }
113}
csharp_detailed:
1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (AccelerationOscillator - AC)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Acceleration Oscillator (AC). We explain *why* code is written this way
7// and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8//
9// [Core Concepts]
10// 1. Bill Williams' AC Theory
11// AC measures the acceleration/deceleration of market momentum.
12// Formula: AC = AO - SMA(AO)
13// [Why] If AO shows momentum, AC shows how fast momentum is changing.
14// Think of it as "acceleration of the trend."
15//
16// 2. Awesome Oscillator (AO) Foundation
17// AO = SMA(Median, ShortPeriod) - SMA(Median, LongPeriod)
18// Median Price = (High + Low) / 2
19// [Why] AO captures the difference between short and long-term momentum.
20// AC then measures the change in that difference.
21//
22// 3. Cascading SMA Chain
23// The calculation flows through multiple stages:
24// Median Price → Short SMA → Long SMA → AO → SMA(AO) → AC
25// [Why] Each stage extracts a different signal from the price data.
26//
27// [Visual] Calculation Flow:
28//
29// ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
30// │ High, Low │
31// │ │ │
32// │ ▼ │
33// │ ┌─────────────────┐ │
34// │ │ Median Price │ = (High + Low) / 2 │
35// │ └────────┬────────┘ │
36// │ │ │
37// │ ├──────────────────────────┐ │
38// │ ▼ ▼ │
39// │ ┌───────────────┐ ┌───────────────┐ │
40// │ │ Short SMA (5) │ │ Long SMA (34) │ │
41// │ └───────┬───────┘ └───────┬───────┘ │
42// │ │ │ │
43// │ └──────────┬───────────────┘ │
44// │ ▼ │
45// │ ┌─────────────┐ │
46// │ │ AO = Short │ │
47// │ │ - Long │ │
48// │ └──────┬──────┘ │
49// │ │ │
50// │ ┌──────────┴──────────┐ │
51// │ ▼ ▼ │
52// │ ┌─────────────┐ ┌─────────────┐ │
53// │ │ AO Value │ │ SMA(AO, 5) │ │
54// │ └──────┬──────┘ └──────┬──────┘ │
55// │ │ │ │
56// │ └──────────┬──────────┘ │
57// │ ▼ │
58// │ ┌─────────────┐ │
59// │ │ AC = AO - │ │
60// │ │ SMA(AO) │ │
61// │ └─────────────┘ │
62// └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
63//
64// [Trading Signals]
65// - AC > 0 and rising: Bullish acceleration
66// - AC > 0 and falling: Bullish deceleration
67// - AC < 0 and falling: Bearish acceleration
68// - AC < 0 and rising: Bearish deceleration
69//
70// =============================================================================
71​
72using System;
73using System.Collections.Generic;
74​
75namespace TechnicalIndicators
76{
77 // =========================================================================
78 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container (CandleData)
79 // =========================================================================
80 //
81 // [Why]
82 // Standardized price data representation. AC uses High and Low
83 // to calculate the Median Price.
84 //
85 // [What]
86 // Encapsulates: Timestamp, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume
87 //
88 // [Where]
89 // Stack allocation (readonly record struct) for GC efficiency.
90 //
91 // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
92 public readonly record struct CandleData(
93 DateTime Timestamp,
94 decimal Open,
95 decimal High,
96 decimal Low,
97 decimal Close,
98 long Volume
99 );
100​
101 // =========================================================================
102 // Logic Explanation: Acceleration Oscillator (Bill Williams)
103 // =========================================================================
104 //
105 // [Why]
106 // Bill Williams developed the AC to detect the earliest possible
107 // changes in momentum. While AO shows momentum direction, AC shows
108 // whether momentum is speeding up or slowing down.
109 //
110 // [What]
111 // AC = AO - SMA(AO, SmoothedPeriod)
112 // Positive AC above zero line = bullish acceleration
113 // Negative AC below zero line = bearish acceleration
114 //
115 // [Who]
116 // - Momentum traders: Early entry signals
117 // - Bill Williams strategy followers
118 // - System developers building Williams indicators suite
119 //
120 // [Where]
121 // Heap allocation (class) due to output collection.
122 //
123 // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
124 public class AccelerationOscillator
125 {
126 // =====================================================================
127 // Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
128 // =====================================================================
129 //
130 // [Why]
131 // Three parameters control AC behavior:
132 // - ShortPeriod: Fast SMA for AO (captures recent momentum)
133 // - LongPeriod: Slow SMA for AO (establishes baseline)
134 // - SmoothedPeriod: SMA period applied to AO for AC calculation
135 //
136 // [What]
137 // Default values (5, 34, 5) are Bill Williams' original settings.
138 //
139 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
140​
141 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
142 // Variable Definition: Short SMA Period
143 // public int ShortPeriod { get; }
144 //
145 // [Role]
146 // Period for the fast SMA of Median Price.
147 // Default 5 captures about one trading week.
148 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
149 public int ShortPeriod { get; }
150​
151 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
152 // Variable Definition: Long SMA Period
153 // public int LongPeriod { get; }
154 //
155 // [Role]
156 // Period for the slow SMA of Median Price.
157 // Default 34 (Fibonacci number) per Bill Williams.
158 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
159 public int LongPeriod { get; }
160​
161 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
162 // Variable Definition: Smoothed Period
163 // public int SmoothedPeriod { get; }
164 //
165 // [Role]
166 // Period for SMA applied to AO to create smoothed reference.
167 // AC = AO - SMA(AO, SmoothedPeriod)
168 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
169 public int SmoothedPeriod { get; }
170​
171 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
172 // Variable Definition: Output Values
173 // public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
174 //
175 // [Role]
176 // Stores final AC values. Positive values indicate bullish
177 // acceleration, negative values indicate bearish acceleration.
178 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
179 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
180​
181 // =====================================================================
182 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
183 // =====================================================================
184 //
185 // [Why]
186 // Stores Bill Williams' standard parameter values.
187 // Note: No validation (trusts user to use sensible values).
188 //
189 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
190 public AccelerationOscillator(int shortPeriod = 5, int longPeriod = 34, int smoothedPeriod = 5)
191 {
192 ShortPeriod = shortPeriod;
193 LongPeriod = longPeriod;
194 SmoothedPeriod = smoothedPeriod;
195 }
196​
197 // =====================================================================
198 // IPO: Calculate
199 // =====================================================================
200 //
201 // [Input]
202 // - candles: IEnumerable<CandleData> - OHLCV price bars
203 //
204 // [Process]
205 // 1. Calculate Median Price = (High + Low) / 2
206 // 2. Calculate Short SMA of Median
207 // 3. Calculate Long SMA of Median
208 // 4. Calculate AO = Short SMA - Long SMA
209 // 5. Calculate SMA of AO
210 // 6. Calculate AC = AO - SMA(AO)
211 //
212 // [Output]
213 // - Populates Values list with AC oscillator values
214 //
215 // =====================================================================
216 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
217 {
218 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
219 // Logic Step 1: Clear and Materialize
220 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
221 Values.Clear();
222 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
223 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
224​
225 // =================================================================
226 // Logic Step 2: Calculate Median Prices
227 // =================================================================
228 //
229 // [Why]
230 // Bill Williams uses Median Price instead of Close because it
231 // better represents the "balance point" of each bar.
232 //
233 // [How]
234 // Median = (High + Low) / 2
235 //
236 // [Visual]
237 // High ─┬─ 120
238 // │
239 // Median │ 115 = (120 + 110) / 2
240 // │
241 // Low ─┴─ 110
242 //
243 // =================================================================
244 var medianPrices = new List<decimal>();
245 foreach (var c in candleList)
246 medianPrices.Add((c.High + c.Low) / 2);
247​
248 // =================================================================
249 // Logic Step 3: Calculate Short and Long SMAs
250 // =================================================================
251 //
252 // [Why]
253 // Two SMAs of different periods capture momentum.
254 // Short SMA reacts faster, Long SMA provides baseline.
255 //
256 // [How]
257 // Sliding window sum for O(1) per-bar efficiency.
258 //
259 // =================================================================
260 var shortSma = CalculateSma(medianPrices, ShortPeriod);
261 var longSma = CalculateSma(medianPrices, LongPeriod);
262​
263 // =================================================================
264 // Logic Step 4: Calculate Awesome Oscillator (AO)
265 // =================================================================
266 //
267 // [Why]
268 // AO is the foundation of AC. It shows the difference between
269 // short and long-term momentum.
270 //
271 // [How]
272 // AO = ShortSMA - LongSMA
273 //
274 // [Visual]
275 // ShortSMA = 115.5, LongSMA = 112.3
276 // AO = 115.5 - 112.3 = +3.2 (bullish momentum)
277 //
278 // =================================================================
279 var ao = new List<decimal?>();
280 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
281 {
282 if (shortSma[i].HasValue && longSma[i].HasValue)
283 ao.Add(shortSma[i]!.Value - longSma[i]!.Value);
284 else
285 ao.Add(null);
286 }
287​
288 // =================================================================
289 // Logic Step 5: Calculate SMA of AO
290 // =================================================================
291 //
292 // [Why]
293 // Smoothing AO creates a reference line. The difference between
294 // raw AO and smoothed AO reveals acceleration.
295 //
296 // [How]
297 // Uses nullable-aware SMA (skips null values).
298 //
299 // =================================================================
300 var aoSma = CalculateSmaFromNullable(ao, SmoothedPeriod);
301​
302 // =================================================================
303 // Logic Step 6: Calculate AC = AO - SMA(AO)
304 // =================================================================
305 //
306 // [Why]
307 // AC shows how fast AO is changing from its average.
308 // Positive AC = AO rising faster than its average (acceleration)
309 // Negative AC = AO falling faster than its average (deceleration)
310 //
311 // [Visual]
312 // AO = +3.2, SMA(AO) = +2.8
313 // AC = 3.2 - 2.8 = +0.4 (momentum accelerating)
314 //
315 // AO = +3.2, SMA(AO) = +3.5
316 // AC = 3.2 - 3.5 = -0.3 (momentum decelerating)
317 //
318 // =================================================================
319 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
320 {
321 if (ao[i].HasValue && aoSma[i].HasValue)
322 Values.Add(ao[i]!.Value - aoSma[i]!.Value);
323 else
324 Values.Add(null);
325 }
326 }
327​
328 // =====================================================================
329 // IPO: CalculateSma (From Non-Nullable List)
330 // =====================================================================
331 //
332 // [Input]
333 // - prices: List<decimal> - Non-nullable price series
334 // - period: int - SMA period
335 //
336 // [Process]
337 // Standard sliding window SMA with O(1) per-bar efficiency.
338 //
339 // [Output]
340 // - List<decimal?> - SMA values (null during warm-up)
341 //
342 // =====================================================================
343 private static List<decimal?> CalculateSma(List<decimal> prices, int period)
344 {
345 var results = new List<decimal?>();
346​
347 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
348 // Variable Definition: Running Sum
349 // [Role] Accumulator for sliding window
350 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
351 decimal sum = 0;
352​
353 for (int i = 0; i < prices.Count; i++)
354 {
355 // Add new value
356 sum += prices[i];
357​
358 // Remove oldest when window full
359 if (i >= period) sum -= prices[i - period];
360​
361 // Output null during warm-up, else average
362 results.Add(i < period - 1 ? null : sum / period);
363 }
364 return results;
365 }
366​
367 // =====================================================================
368 // IPO: CalculateSmaFromNullable (From Nullable List)
369 // =====================================================================
370 //
371 // [Input]
372 // - source: List<decimal?> - Nullable value series
373 // - period: int - SMA period
374 //
375 // [Process]
376 // 1. Skip null values (don't count towards period)
377 // 2. Use Queue for efficient window management
378 // 3. Track valid count separately from index
379 //
380 // [Output]
381 // - List<decimal?> - SMA values (null when insufficient valid values)
382 //
383 // [Visual] Queue-Based Sliding Window:
384 //
385 // source: [null, null, 5.0, 3.2, 4.1, 6.0, ...]
386 // Queue evolution:
387 // i=0: null → skip
388 // i=1: null → skip
389 // i=2: 5.0 → Queue: [5.0], validCount=1
390 // i=3: 3.2 → Queue: [5.0, 3.2], validCount=2
391 // i=4: 4.1 → Queue: [5.0, 3.2, 4.1], validCount=3
392 // i=5: 6.0 → Queue: [3.2, 4.1, 6.0], validCount=4 (5.0 dequeued)
393 //
394 // =====================================================================
395 private static List<decimal?> CalculateSmaFromNullable(List<decimal?> source, int period)
396 {
397 var results = new List<decimal?>();
398​
399 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
400 // Variable Definition: Running Sum and Queue
401 // [Role] Track window contents and maintain sum
402 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
403 decimal sum = 0;
404 int validCount = 0;
405 var queue = new Queue<decimal>();
406​
407 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
408 {
409 // -------------------------------------------------------------
410 // Logic Step 1: Handle Null Values
411 //
412 // [Decision] Is source[i] null?
413 // [True] Propagate null, don't count
414 // -------------------------------------------------------------
415 if (!source[i].HasValue)
416 {
417 results.Add(null);
418 continue;
419 }
420​
421 // -------------------------------------------------------------
422 // Logic Step 2: Add Value to Window
423 // -------------------------------------------------------------
424 validCount++;
425 sum += source[i]!.Value;
426 queue.Enqueue(source[i]!.Value);
427​
428 // -------------------------------------------------------------
429 // Logic Step 3: Remove Oldest if Window Exceeds Period
430 // -------------------------------------------------------------
431 if (queue.Count > period)
432 sum -= queue.Dequeue();
433​
434 // -------------------------------------------------------------
435 // Logic Step 4: Output SMA or Null
436 // -------------------------------------------------------------
437 results.Add(validCount < period ? null : sum / period);
438 }
439 return results;
440 }
441​
442 // =====================================================================
443 // Static Convenience Wrapper (3-Step Pattern)
444 // =====================================================================
445 //
446 // [Why]
447 // Provides functional-style API for one-liner calculations.
448 //
449 // [How]
450 // 1. Instantiation: Create new AC instance
451 // 2. Execution: Run calculation
452 // 3. Extraction: Return AC values
453 //
454 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
455 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int shortPeriod = 5, int longPeriod = 34, int smoothedPeriod = 5)
456 {
457 // 1. Instantiation
458 var ac = new AccelerationOscillator(shortPeriod, longPeriod, smoothedPeriod);
459​
460 // 2. Execution
461 ac.Calculate(candles);
462​
463 // 3. Extraction
464 return ac.Values;
465 }
466 }
467}
python_simple:
1from collections import deque
2​
3class AccelerationOscillator:
4 """
5 Acceleration Oscillator (AO / AC)
6 Measues acceleration of momentum.
7 AC = AO - SMA(AO, 5)
8 """
9 def __init__(self, short_period=5, long_period=34, smoothed_period=5):
10 self.short_period = short_period
11 self.long_period = long_period
12 self.smoothed_period = smoothed_period
13 self.values = []
14​
15 def calculate(self, candles):
16 self.values.clear()
17 if len(candles) == 0: return
18​
19 # 1. Median Prices
20 medians = [(c['high'] + c['low'])/2 for c in candles]
21​
22 # 2. AO = SMA(5) - SMA(34)
23 short_sma = self._sma(medians, self.short_period)
24 long_sma = self._sma(medians, self.long_period)
25
26 ao = []
27 for i in range(len(candles)):
28 if short_sma[i] is not None and long_sma[i] is not None:
29 ao.append(short_sma[i] - long_sma[i])
30 else:
31 ao.append(None)
32​
33 # 3. SMA of AO
34 ao_sma = self._sma_nullable(ao, self.smoothed_period)
35​
36 # 4. AC = AO - SMA(AO)
37 for i in range(len(candles)):
38 if ao[i] is not None and ao_sma[i] is not None:
39 self.values.append(ao[i] - ao_sma[i])
40 else:
41 self.values.append(None)
42​
43 def _sma(self, source, period):
44 res = []
45 s = 0.0
46 for i in range(len(source)):
47 s += source[i]
48 if i >= period: s -= source[i - period]
49 res.append(s/period if i >= period - 1 else None)
50 return res
51​
52 def _sma_nullable(self, source, period):
53 res = []
54 s = 0.0
55 window = deque()
56 for i in range(len(source)):
57 if source[i] is None:
58 res.append(None)
59 continue
60
61 val = source[i]
62 s += val
63 window.append(val)
64
65 if len(window) > period: s -= window.popleft()
66
67 res.append(s/period if len(window) >= period else None)
68 return res
69​
70def calculate(candles, short=5, long=34, smooth=5):
71 ac = AccelerationOscillator(short, long, smooth)
72 ac.calculate(candles)
73 return ac.values
python_detailed:
1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (AccelerationOscillator - AC)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Acceleration Oscillator (AC). We explain *why* code is written this way
7# and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Momentum of Momentum
11# AC measures the acceleration (rate of change) of the Awesome Oscillator.
12# If AO measures momentum, AC measures "momentum of momentum" - how fast
13# momentum itself is changing. O(N) complexity for full calculation.
14#
15# 2. Three-Layer SMA Pipeline
16# Layer 1: Short SMA of median prices (fast signal)
17# Layer 2: Long SMA of median prices (slow signal)
18# Layer 3: AO = Short SMA - Long SMA
19# Layer 4: AC = AO - SMA(AO) (detrended AO)
20#
21# 3. Nullable SMA Handling
22# When source data contains None values (insufficient history),
23# the SMA must skip those values rather than treating them as zero.
24# This requires a queue-based approach instead of simple sliding window.
25#
26# =============================================================================
27​
28​
29# -------------------------------------------------------------
30# Type-Level Explanation: AccelerationOscillator (class)
31#
32# [Why] Encapsulates multi-stage calculation with intermediate results.
33# State management allows reuse and inspection of internals.
34#
35# [What] Computes AC = AO - SMA(AO), where AO = SMA(short) - SMA(long).
36# Three configurable periods: short, long, smoothed.
37#
38# [Who] Bill Williams trading system users, momentum traders.
39#
40# [Where] Heap allocation - stores multiple intermediate lists.
41#
42# Why three separate periods?
43# 1. short_period: Captures immediate momentum (default 5)
44# 2. long_period: Captures underlying trend momentum (default 34)
45# 3. smoothed_period: Smooths the difference (default 5)
46# -------------------------------------------------------------
47class AccelerationOscillator:
48​
49 # -------------------------------------------------------------
50 # Constructor: __init__
51 #
52 # [Why] Store configuration parameters for later use.
53 # No validation here - Bill Williams system allows any periods.
54 #
55 # [What] short_period: Fast SMA window (default 5)
56 # long_period: Slow SMA window (default 34)
57 # smoothed_period: AO smoothing window (default 5)
58 # -------------------------------------------------------------
59 def __init__(self, short_period=5, long_period=34, smoothed_period=5):
60​
61 # -------------------------------------------------------------
62 # Variable Definition: short_period
63 # self.short_period = short_period
64 #
65 # [Role]
66 # Fast-moving average window. Smaller = more responsive to price.
67 #
68 # [Type Choice]
69 # int - Discrete bar count.
70 # -------------------------------------------------------------
71 self.short_period = short_period
72​
73 # -------------------------------------------------------------
74 # Variable Definition: long_period
75 # self.long_period = long_period
76 #
77 # [Role]
78 # Slow-moving average window. Larger = more stable baseline.
79 #
80 # [Type Choice]
81 # int - Discrete bar count.
82 # -------------------------------------------------------------
83 self.long_period = long_period
84​
85 # -------------------------------------------------------------
86 # Variable Definition: smoothed_period
87 # self.smoothed_period = smoothed_period
88 #
89 # [Role]
90 # Window for smoothing the Awesome Oscillator.
91 # Creates the "baseline" that AC deviates from.
92 #
93 # [Type Choice]
94 # int - Discrete bar count.
95 # -------------------------------------------------------------
96 self.smoothed_period = smoothed_period
97​
98 # -------------------------------------------------------------
99 # Variable Definition: values
100 # self.values = []
101 #
102 # [Role]
103 # Final AC output. None for insufficient data, float otherwise.
104 #
105 # [Type Choice]
106 # list - Dynamic size matching input length.
107 # -------------------------------------------------------------
108 self.values = []
109​
110​
111 # =============================================================================
112 # IPO: calculate
113 # =============================================================================
114 #
115 # [Input]
116 # - candles: list[dict] - Each dict has 'high', 'low' keys.
117 #
118 # [Process]
119 # 1. Calculate median prices: (high + low) / 2
120 # 2. Calculate short SMA of median prices
121 # 3. Calculate long SMA of median prices
122 # 4. Calculate AO = short_sma - long_sma
123 # 5. Calculate SMA of AO (handling None values)
124 # 6. Calculate AC = AO - SMA(AO)
125 #
126 # [Output]
127 # - None (results stored in self.values)
128 # =============================================================================
129 def calculate(self, candles):
130​
131 # -------------------------------------------------------------
132 # Logic Step 1: State Reset
133 #
134 # [Why] (Intent)
135 # Clear previous results for instance reuse.
136 # -------------------------------------------------------------
137 self.values.clear()
138​
139 # -------------------------------------------------------------
140 # Logic Step 2: Empty Input Guard
141 #
142 # [Decision]
143 # Is there any data to process?
144 #
145 # [True Branch: No Data]
146 # Return immediately with empty results.
147 #
148 # [False Branch: Has Data]
149 # Proceed with calculation.
150 # -------------------------------------------------------------
151 if len(candles) == 0:
152 return
153​
154 # -------------------------------------------------------------
155 # Logic Step 3: Calculate Median Prices
156 #
157 # [Why] (Intent)
158 # Median price = (High + Low) / 2 is Bill Williams' standard.
159 # It represents the "fair value" for each bar, ignoring
160 # open/close quirks.
161 #
162 # [How] (Logic)
163 # List comprehension for O(N) single-pass transformation.
164 #
165 # [Visual]
166 # candle: {high: 105, low: 95}
167 # median = (105 + 95) / 2 = 100
168 # -------------------------------------------------------------
169 median_prices = [(c['high'] + c['low']) / 2 for c in candles]
170​
171 # -------------------------------------------------------------
172 # Logic Step 4: Calculate Short and Long SMAs
173 #
174 # [Why] (Intent)
175 # Two SMAs of different periods create momentum detection.
176 # Short SMA responds quickly, Long SMA is stable.
177 #
178 # [How] (Logic)
179 # Delegate to _calc_sma helper (sliding window algorithm).
180 #
181 # [Visual]
182 # median_prices: [100, 102, 101, 103, 105, ...]
183 # short_sma(5): [None, None, None, None, 102.2, ...]
184 # long_sma(34): [None x 33, first_value, ...]
185 # -------------------------------------------------------------
186 short_sma = self._calc_sma(median_prices, self.short_period)
187 long_sma = self._calc_sma(median_prices, self.long_period)
188​
189 # -------------------------------------------------------------
190 # Logic Step 5: Calculate Awesome Oscillator (AO)
191 #
192 # [Why] (Intent)
193 # AO = Short SMA - Long SMA measures momentum.
194 # Positive AO = bullish momentum, Negative AO = bearish.
195 #
196 # [How] (Logic)
197 # Element-wise subtraction. Both must be non-None for valid result.
198 #
199 # [Visual]
200 # short_sma: [None, None, 50.0, 51.0, 52.0]
201 # long_sma: [None, None, None, None, 50.5]
202 # ao: [None, None, None, None, 1.5]
203 # ↑ ↑ ↑
204 # short valid long valid both valid
205 # -------------------------------------------------------------
206 ao = []
207 for i in range(len(candles)):
208 if short_sma[i] is not None and long_sma[i] is not None:
209 ao.append(short_sma[i] - long_sma[i])
210 else:
211 ao.append(None)
212​
213 # -------------------------------------------------------------
214 # Logic Step 6: Smooth the AO (Nullable-Safe SMA)
215 #
216 # [Why] (Intent)
217 # Create a baseline for AO. AC will measure deviation from this.
218 #
219 # [How] (Logic)
220 # Use _calc_sma_nullable which handles None values gracefully.
221 # None values are skipped, not counted as zero.
222 # -------------------------------------------------------------
223 ao_sma = self._calc_sma_nullable(ao, self.smoothed_period)
224​
225 # -------------------------------------------------------------
226 # Logic Step 7: Calculate Acceleration Oscillator (AC)
227 #
228 # [Why] (Intent)
229 # AC = AO - SMA(AO) shows acceleration of momentum.
230 # Positive AC = momentum increasing, Negative = decreasing.
231 #
232 # [How] (Logic)
233 # Element-wise subtraction. Both must be non-None.
234 #
235 # [Visual]
236 # ao: [None, None, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5]
237 # ao_sma: [None, None, None, None, 2.0]
238 # ac: [None, None, None, None, 0.5]
239 # ↑
240 # 2.5 - 2.0 = 0.5 (accelerating!)
241 # -------------------------------------------------------------
242 for i in range(len(candles)):
243 if ao[i] is not None and ao_sma[i] is not None:
244 self.values.append(ao[i] - ao_sma[i])
245 else:
246 self.values.append(None)
247​
248​
249 # =============================================================================
250 # IPO: _calc_sma (Private Helper)
251 # =============================================================================
252 #
253 # [Input]
254 # - prices: list[float] - Non-nullable price series.
255 # - period: int - SMA window size.
256 #
257 # [Process]
258 # - Sliding window sum with O(1) per-element update.
259 #
260 # [Output]
261 # - list[float|None] - SMA values, None for first (period-1) elements.
262 #
263 # [Why This Approach?]
264 # Sliding window avoids recomputing full sum each iteration.
265 # O(N) total instead of O(N*period).
266 # =============================================================================
267 def _calc_sma(self, prices, period):
268​
269 results = []
270 s = 0 # Running sum
271​
272 # -------------------------------------------------------------
273 # Logic Step: Sliding Window SMA
274 #
275 # [Why] (Intent)
276 # Maintain running sum. Add new element, subtract oldest.
277 #
278 # [How] (Logic)
279 # - Always add current price to sum
280 # - If past period, subtract the element leaving the window
281 # - Output None until we have 'period' elements
282 #
283 # [Visual]
284 # period = 3
285 # prices: [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]
286 # i=0: s=10, result=None (need 2 more)
287 # i=1: s=30, result=None (need 1 more)
288 # i=2: s=60, result=20.0 ← first valid SMA
289 # i=3: s=60-10+40=90, result=30.0
290 # i=4: s=90-20+50=120,result=40.0
291 # -------------------------------------------------------------
292 for i in range(len(prices)):
293 s += prices[i]
294​
295 if i >= period:
296 # Remove oldest element leaving the window
297 s -= prices[i - period]
298​
299 # Output None until window is full
300 results.append(None if i < period - 1 else s / period)
301​
302 return results
303​
304​
305 # =============================================================================
306 # IPO: _calc_sma_nullable (Private Helper)
307 # =============================================================================
308 #
309 # [Input]
310 # - source: list[float|None] - May contain None values.
311 # - period: int - SMA window size.
312 #
313 # [Process]
314 # - Queue-based approach that skips None values.
315 # - Only outputs when queue has exactly 'period' valid elements.
316 #
317 # [Output]
318 # - list[float|None] - SMA values.
319 #
320 # [Why This Approach?]
321 # Standard sliding window breaks with None values.
322 # Queue tracks only valid values and their count.
323 # =============================================================================
324 def _calc_sma_nullable(self, source, period):
325​
326 results = []
327 s = 0 # Running sum of valid values
328 queue = [] # Queue of valid values in window
329​
330 # -------------------------------------------------------------
331 # Logic Step: Queue-Based Nullable SMA
332 #
333 # [Why] (Intent)
334 # None values shouldn't count toward period.
335 # Only average 'period' valid values.
336 #
337 # [How] (Logic)
338 # - Skip None inputs entirely (append None to output)
339 # - For valid inputs: add to sum and queue
340 # - If queue exceeds period: remove oldest from sum
341 # - Output SMA only when queue has 'period' elements
342 #
343 # [Visual]
344 # source: [None, 10, 20, None, 30, 40, 50]
345 # period = 3
346 #
347 # i=0: None → skip, output None
348 # i=1: queue=[10] → len<3, output None
349 # i=2: queue=[10,20] → len<3, output None
350 # i=3: None → skip, output None
351 # i=4: queue=[10,20,30] → len=3! output=20.0
352 # i=5: queue=[20,30,40] → pop 10, output=30.0
353 # i=6: queue=[30,40,50] → pop 20, output=40.0
354 # -------------------------------------------------------------
355 for i in range(len(source)):
356​
357 # Skip None values
358 if source[i] is None:
359 results.append(None)
360 continue
361​
362 # Add valid value to sum and queue
363 s += source[i]
364 queue.append(source[i])
365​
366 # Maintain window size
367 if len(queue) > period:
368 s -= queue.pop(0)
369​
370 # Output SMA only when we have enough valid values
371 results.append(None if len(queue) < period else s / period)
372​
373 return results
374​
375​
376# =============================================================================
377# Static Wrapper Function: calculate
378# =============================================================================
379#
380# [Why]
381# Provides functional API for one-shot calculations without instance management.
382#
383# [Pattern: 3-Step Static Wrapper]
384# 1. Instantiation - Create temporary instance
385# 2. Execution - Process data
386# 3. Extraction - Return results only
387# =============================================================================
388def calculate(candles, short_period=5, long_period=34, smoothed_period=5):
389 # 1. Instantiation
390 ac = AccelerationOscillator(short_period, long_period, smoothed_period)
391​
392 # 2. Execution
393 ac.calculate(candles)
394​
395 # 3. Extraction
396 return ac.values
